reviewText: Well, like any movie made from a book, they had to leave a lot out, and they had to change some things. But it's still a well-done movie, and I enjoyed it.Eddie Hodges plays Huck, and I'm sure I've seen him elsewhere, but I admit I don't remember where. Archie Moore, who was a champion boxer before he took up acting, plays Jim, and shows he's quite a good actor. It would be interesting to know what other films he's done. Neville Brand plays Pap, as mean as he can be.Tony Randall plays the smooth-talking con man who calls himself the lost King of France, and Mickey Shaughnessy is the Duke. Patty McCormack (remember her? I think she played Pollyanna.) is the younger sister who does not believe the King and the Duke and Huck are their long-lost relatives from England. Sterling Holloway is the town barber who first announces the arrival of the English relatives when the three frauds show up, and then again when the real English relatives show up. Andy Devine plays the circus manager who takes in, and is taken in, by Huck and Jim, to keep Jim away from the slave-catchers. Buster Keaton plays the long-suffering lion-tamer.The incidents in the movie are enough like the book that I wouldn't want to tell the story over again. But you can tell with all those excellent talents listed above -- and more -- that it's a well-made movie version of a great story.
summary: One of the Better Versions of this Much-Filmed Favorite

reviewText: This film is laughably bad, unless you paid for the item in which case you may feel more like crying than laughing.  With a few exceptions, including Randall, the acting is horrible.  Jim and Huck look more like healthy California actors than a poor, deprived 19th century urchin and slave.  Find another version of this story.

reviewText: truth be told, there has never been a fully satisfactory film adaptation of twains masterpiece, and i doubt there ever could be -- but taken on its own terms this is a charming movie. originally planned as a big-screen musical (i leave it to others to give that particular contorted history, but you can still hear several of the dumped songs in the background score), it finally emerged as a straight telling of the most famous parts (read least controversial) of twains novel. eddie hodges is a credible huck and boxing great archie moore is a surprisingly effective jim, with strong supporting work from tony randall and mickey shaughnessy as the the dauphin and the duke, and (among others) patty mccormack, andy devine, and the too-little-seen buster keaton. like i said, there will never be a perfect screen huck, but this comes as close as any.
summary: appreciate this adaptation on its own terms

reviewText: I remember watching a version of Huckleberry Finn when I was a young boy and it was broadcast in black and white. I thought this was it but alas it is not. Because of ethnic changes and the added "musical" dialog, it is okay for family viewing but as for me I liked the original broadcast I had watched back then, which after having read the book seemed to be closer to the printed story line than any tother version since then
summary: Not the one I was looking for

reviewText: "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" has been filmed many times overthe years and I believe this version to be the best.Made in 1960, it stars Eddie Hodges in the title role. This youngboy looks and acts the part to perfection and he is well supportedby a strong cast of well known movie stars some who appear incameo type roles. They include:Tony RandallMickey ShaughnessyNeville BrandAndy DevineSherry JacksonBuster KeatonFindlay CurrieJohn CarradineRoyal DanoArchie Moore appears as Huck's friend Jim.The well known story is about Huckleberry Finn, a young boy whofor personal reasons is dissatisfied with his mundane life, sohe sets off with Jim a runaway slave on a trip by raft down theMississippi River in search of adventure.The movie is well constructed and the various characters morethan interesting. This version stands out from the crowd as itappears to be more complete than the others, containing segmentsfrom the story missing from other film versions.Good family entertainment.
